bibl.title: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Henry Rose Carter, September 24, 1923

div1.p: Russell sends Carter letters regarding a suspected yellow fever death. Russell does not want Carter to feel obliged to answer letters during Carter's convalescence.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Henry Rose Carter, September 24, 1923

September 24, 1923.
CABLE ADDRESS “INTERCOM”
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter of September fourteenth, with regard to the
Corona case, has been received.

For your information, I am enclosing copies of the reports enc. 1; enc. 2; enc. 3; enc. 4
of Doctors Noguchi and Darling on the sections of liver of this case,
which show in addition to very extensive post-mortem changes that the
patient suffered with cirrhosis of the liver and possibly with malaria.
In so far as one can judge from such inferior specimens, there is
practically nothing to indicate that he had yellow fever. The gas
bacillus infection referred to in the reports is without much doubt
due to post-mortem change, and it is improbable that it had anything to
do with his death. I am forwarding copies of these reports to Doctor
Connor in Mexico, and he will, of course, give copies to Doctor Perrin
and to Doctor Pruneda.

I am very much afraid that our numerous letters are not
helping you in your convalescence. We shall continue to send them,
but please do not feel under the slightest obligation to answer them,
Doctor H. R. Carter,
September 24, 1923.
2.
or even to read them, until such time as you really feel that
you can do so without tiring.
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely, F F Russell Doctor H. R. Carter,
Badin Hospital,
Badin, North Carolina.
